body: @niabot Can you please file a new bug report for slow code-completion of constructor arguments, and reference it from this issue? Thank you.

Are you referring to the squishing of changes or are you talking about the changes to the BreakpointAnnotationProvider? Where do I file the ICLA anyway? Sorry about this, I am a beginner in regards to contributing things and git.

I thought we hadn't your name and email address, but in fact we do. 
ICLA is not mandatory for this, so this is ready for review. Sorry for the noise.

@SirIntellegence well, the one other thing at the beginning of the contributor guidelines suggests opening a JIRA ticket and/or starting a discussion on the dev@ mailing list prior to making a pull request.  I absolutely understand the need for this - I'm currently doing the same thing you were doing changing the `netbeans.buildnumber` and did not realise this broke import/export of settings because I've disabled that.  I'm a -1 to this way of fixing it though.

Incidentally, the other current workaround to your immediate problem might be to dynamically rewrite the `currentVersion` branding - wonder if this still works? http://wiki.netbeans.org/DevFaqAutoUpdateBranding

I agree that this is not the best fix, but I am not familiar enough with everything to know the best way to do it. Also, import/export settings is expecting "(Build " to be in the contents of `netbeans.buildnumber` followed by a Date/Time formatted as a long and `currentVersion` is not used in the about window.
You are right that one could update the branding bundle string, but doing that on update or dynamically at the moment I do believe would be a nightmare. Changing it on update would require the user to always have write permission to the install directory which may require the user to start the application as an administrator (or root). Dynamically changing it would be a nightmare because I don't know how one would go about doing that.

> and `currentVersion` is not used in the about window.

https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/blob/master/o.n.core/src/org/netbeans/core/ui/ProductInformationPanel.java#L273
As in the system property, not the bundle key. Sorry for the ambiguity.

I pushed an update, that:

- Changes resulting filename to rat-appendix.txt
- Integrates rat-exclusions into rat-appendix.txt to have one file to offer reviewers
- tweaks layout of rat-appendix.txt
- adjustes license infos
- squashes update commits into their base commits.

@jlahoda thank you for looking through this. I agree, that it can be improved (better explanation texts, links, format the rat-appendix file as html to make it more readable, ...).

I merge this now nonetheless, as I want to see the fallout before putting more work into this
@matthiasblaesing, yes, I think merging this is fine, I just was noting what we could enhance for the future.
OK from me too.
Looks good to me.

If I'm not mistaken the intention is here to prepare the JARs when they are individually deployed to maven central.

The created jars look good and the license content looks sane and for the individual jars the single file form of the license file look approriate.

One think I noticed while building and thinking about the maven central part, was that I routinely fetch sources for dependencies to understand failure/investigate. This lead me to the sources-zip task. The generated source zips won't survie a review, but based on the work done till this, I suggest this:

```diff
# This patch file was generated by NetBeans IDE
# It uses platform neutral UTF-8 encoding and \n newlines.
--- a/nbbuild/templates/projectized.xml
+++ b/nbbuild/templates/projectized.xml
@@ -372,9 +372,26 @@
     <target name="netbeans" depends="projectized-common.netbeans,check-sigtest"/>
 -->    
     <target name="sources-zip" depends="build-init, check-sources-exist" if="sources.exist" description="Simple sources zip creation intended for use in maven repository.">
+        
+        <taskdef name="createlicensesummary" classname="org.netbeans.nbbuild.extlibs.CreateLicenseSummary" classpath="${nbantext.jar}"/>
+        <property name="module.name.temp" location="." />
+        <basename property="module.name" file="${module.name.temp}" />
+        <mkdir dir="${build.classes.dir}/META-INF" />
+        <createlicensesummary licenseStub="${nb_all}/LICENSE"
+                              noticeStub="${nb_all}/nbbuild/notice-stub.txt"
+                              nball="${nb_all}"
+                              license="${build.dir}/LICENSE"
+                              notice="${build.dir}/NOTICE"
+                              binary="false"
+                              modules="${module.name}"
+        />
+        
         <mkdir dir="${netbeans.zipped.sources.dir}"/>
-        <zip zipfile="${netbeans.zipped.sources.dir}/${code.name.base.dashes}.zip"
-             basedir="${src.dir}"/>
+        <zip zipfile="${netbeans.zipped.sources.dir}/${code.name.base.dashes}.zip">
+            <zipfileset dir="${src.dir}" />
+            <zipfileset dir="${build.dir}" prefix="META-INF" includes="LICENSE NOTICE" />
+            <zipfileset dir="${nb_all}" prefix="META-INF" includes="DISCLAIMER" />
+        </zip>
     </target>
```

In effect this would transfer your binary approach to the source files and place the license info in the META-INF directory of the source jar.
So, what is the status of this then?

AFAIK status of this PR is "pending review by committers". 
This will require some patience, as people is busy doing other things (working out the next 9.0-rc3 release, paying taxes by the end of January or picking up children at school, who knows :-)).
OK, merging.
Great, thanks a lot.

One functional comment: the new API essentially allows to replace information in the about box by any module in the system. It should not be the case, the about box have at least a mandatory part that describes the platform or distribution (application). Optionally additional information collected from modules.
Your AboutMessageOverride seems as if it should not be registered in default Lookup, but passed through e.g. system property or a file on classpath (among the startup JARs), so it is strictly under the control of the distribution packager.
As I said before, I don't know how to do that or I would have done so.
Just checking, I would do some Class.forName(System.getProperty("SomePropHere"))? If that is the case, where would the best place to put the property then? Maybe in the branding strings?
Submitted to JIRA: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-352

I wonder: is there a chance to move this into some existing directory (or a sub-directory of thereof)? E.g. nbbuild/packaging/snap, or ide/packaging/snap something line that? I think that would be cleaner, and also would help to pack that directory into a source distro (because currently with this patch, I don't think this directory would be packed into the source zip).
Looked at this, looks good.
Thanks for the comments! I moved the snap folder under nbbuild/packaging snapcraft shall be executed from that directory.
Sweet, thanks for doing this! :)

FWIW (sorry I forgot to write about this), the request was that even jars inside the binary distribution should have the LICENSE/NOTICE, even if they are not a standalone distribution. But correct, it is useful for Maven as well.
I meant to have that message be 'tab to space', not 'space to tab'
I'd rather create one which just catches the CNFE.

This seems to fix only the symptom and not the cause. The cause is the bad separation from the javahelp jar. (Which I am not entirely certain but might be complicated to pull off since we re-export the JavaHelp APIs, no?)

Anyhow, it might be a good temporary workaround but ideally we should use the module system somehow and not rely on NCDFE / CNFE checks and --cp:a...

Well, I guess JavaHelp has some license issues so this one has happened: https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/pull/249/commits/bdb74770a17d5484b9c1fe068c98f41ced7fe07b
We might create another issue to mend this stuff when the fate of the help system get decided.
I tested this and this works
I tested too and now it works as expected.

IMO there is no requirement to provide the LICENSE/NOTICE files inside jars which are not distributed separately. More convenient: yes, and useful for Maven: definitely. But not legally required AFAIK.
This looks like a much cleaner fix than the one I suggested. :)

+1
This [icon](https://github.com/JaroslavTulach/incubator-netbeans/blob/ba804984126e64f9eba57394169bd9af007f72f7/profiler.heapwalker/src/org/netbeans/modules/profiler/heapwalk/ui/icons/impl/oqlConsole.png) looks OK.
Geertjan, can you please review my change and merge it when you find it OK? Thanks.

I think this is a fine idea. The travis build failed, though, seems(?) that nbjunit is not yet built when the openide.util.lookup's tests are being built. Not sure why exactly is that, needs investigation.

I saw two thinks here:

1. It would be good if the intention of the patch would be documented (why and how) - would updating to a newer version of equinox also be an option?
2. I would prefer, that the equinox source code is not added as a submodule (see: https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/pull/421/files#diff-0c8d99427179470b4f6a7e707e07fc42). I don't see a reason to include the directory/submodule in the repository.

The procedure looks sensible (maybe we can build it on-the-fly in the future, but for now it looks good).

Looks good to me, thanks for making the PR.

​
--emi
​

-------- Original Message --------
 On 15 February 2018 5:33 PM, Jaroslav Tulach <notifications@github.com> wrote:

>
>@JaroslavTulach requested your review on: apache/incubator-netbeans#422 Backport of emilianbold's transaction for bug #250103.
>
>
>—
>You are receiving this because your review was requested.
>Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.
>
>
>

> The procedure looks sensible

Great. That is probably all legal needs. Thanks for the review.

> (maybe we can build it on-the-fly in the future, but for now it looks good)
> would updating to a newer version of equinox also be an option?

I think it is desirable to update to new version of Equinox and use the pristine JAR as provided by Eclipse in the future. We just need to find somebody to do it...

> equinox source code is not added as a submodule

No Equinox sources are in our repository. Just the binary reference and shell script to produce the binary.

With regard to:
> > I would prefer, that the equinox source code is not added as a submodule
>
> No Equinox sources are in our repository. Just the binary reference and shell  script to produce the binary.

You included the directory `netbinox/external/rt.equinox.framework` - this is recorded as a submodule (a clone from a foreign repository). On my system this ends with:

```
matthias@athena:~/src/incubator-netbeans$ git submodule status --recursive
fatal: no submodule mapping found in .gitmodules for path 'netbinox/external/rt.equinox.framework'
matthias@athena:~/src/incubator-netbeans$ 
```

I would just remove that directory from the PR, as it is created by the shell script if it is needed.

Right, `++` isn't atomic. I just thought it doesn't matter. That it is not important to get warnings all the time.

`AtomicInteger` was my original attempt too. Then I realized the above, plus the fact it should be `AtomicLong` - I can make it `AtomicLong` or `AtomicInteger` if desirable.
I have decided that #416 is a better fix than this one.
Sorry, about all the commits in this PR that don't relate to this PR -- if someone can advise how to get rid of them, that would be great. Only the last commit is applicable here.
This change was done on the master branch. I moved them to their own branch, so this one will be closed and a new pull request opened with the correct branch.

I think using `AtomicLong` would be preferable for the reason that potentially nondeterministic behavior will be avoided. Also, developers who examine this part of the code base might have the same thoughts as Jan, and would not know why this does not matter.

Probably, your master branch has merge commits. Merge commits were created when you merged the upstream master branch into your master branch. This is not a fast-forward merge. e.g. This(https://github.com/geertjanw/incubator-netbeans/commit/eb425e4318aa3c391539a0ad5965c002f45dce0a) does not exist in the upstream master branch.
So you should clean up your master branch.

I assume that apache/incubator-netbeans repository is added as upstream.

The simplest way is removing your repository. Then fork apache/incubator-netbeans repository again.

Although I cannot take responsibility...
Another way:
```
git fetch upstream
git checkout master
git reset --hard upstream/master
git push -f origin master // push forcibly

git checkout -b your-new-branch
```
Anyone, Is this way wrong?
Ah, good idea. I will delete the repo and fork from scratch.

Maybe I'm not a proper person to review this. So, I just would like to say about your git commits.

It would be nice if you can rebase & squash your commits yourself (see https://git-scm.com/book/id/v2/Git-Tools-Rewriting-History).

You should add the issue number([NETBEANS-352]) to your commit message. (see other PRs and Contribution Guidelines (4): https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=74681408#SubmittingPullRequestonApacheNetBeans(incubating)-ContributionGuidelines)

Thanks for your work!

Ya, these are commits I made beforehand. I moved the branch up through the changes with the "rebase" command. The changes already existed, I just changed what branch it was on. I plan on doing those things in the future though.
OK, using `AtomicLong`.
Looks good to me

So the removing text/x-java-string embedding happens only for the strings, which you want to colorize as javascript. Mila mentioned that probably there is a way how to say which embedding is important fro coloring.

There is a ticket in bugzilla, where we need to change coloring for Java strings, to for example JS, XML or SQL or whatever you can use inside strings (RegEx too) But this is an other ticket/topic. Only to let you know that making one embedding language, inside a string, higher prioritized as an other (which could be) is not a good option. With a hint like: "Treat this string as SQL or HTML or JS" that will treat the string with the right embedding provider/MimeType.

As I said, only to let you know that. For know, I think it is fine to make it as it is now. For later, we there is a change needed for Java strings, to support more syntax highlighting/code completion inside Java strings. My 2 cents.

@Chris2011 Bugzilla, not JIRA?  That would be a good one to make sure comes across.  I'd personally like to be able to treat the contents of a Java String as fragments of Java, which might also be useful in things like annotation processors.

@neilcsmith-net atm there is only one ticket: https://netbeans.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=267488 means: `support HTML syntax highlighting and code completion inside JS strings`. But we have a lot of mroe SQL in Java Strings, or XML or HTML iniside Java Strings. Or HTML, SQL inside PHP strings. I thought there are already tickets for those cases but unfortunately not. I will create that later. That one, that I posted, was not yet migrated to JIRA, but soon I will.

The thing is, to treat strings not only as strings is bringing other languages to it. IntelliJ can treat strings with hints for RegEx or other languages like SQL.

https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/using-language-injections.html here is an approach as from IntelliJ. They know annotations for settings languages, which I not prefer because there is a real change in your code for that. The other one is via comment. The one, that I really prefer is the hint, where you can set the language of the string manually w/o comment or annotation.

But I think this is really out of topic and should be discussed in the tickets that I want to create later.
@neilcsmith-net here is a similar one: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-30 But it is about only to adding it to the @Query annotation which is not enough, because it is still a string.

@JaroslavTulach @neilcsmith-net Back to topic, for me it seems okish for the first time. When the next EmbeddingProvider is coming, we need a rethink. If the others sees the same ok, if not we should rethink it now.
@ppisl if there is already such "simple" solution or way, that would be better.

I'm fine with removing all the JavaFX samples, as they don't work (neither in 8.2 nor in 9), but:

Why is the licensing unclear? My understanding was, that everything from the initial checkin was taken from the data oracle donated. As many important third-party files were removed before that set was created (the XSDs and DTDs we readded), I'd expect, that these files were considered to be donatable by oracle. In turn this would mean, that the licensing is totally clear: They are ALv2.

Thank you for your work!

They work fine in 8.2, I just tried the Xylophone sample there, no problems. Will take a look as well to see in Apache NetBeans (incubating) 9.0 Beta.

Re your other point. I agree. But if I have a choice between going into a discussion about this versus simply removing this sample, in terms of time and priority, I'd prefer to simply remove the sample.
OK, merging.
Requested the review, not sure if special permissions are needed.
Thanks, merging.
I think we will resubmit later from the jdk18_3 branch.
Makes sense to me, thanks for doing this.

@JaroslavTulach the actual issue here cannot be handled by branding as far as I can see - there needs to be a way to filter / change the arguments passed into `NbBundle.getMessage()` to do this.  As I mentioned on the first PR for this, I'm -1 to adding a new API to try and fix this one issue, because it's not the only place I've seen this problem.  I did suggest we provide a way to filter input arguments - https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/pull/393#issuecomment-362662452  What would be your thoughts on trying to do that instead?
https://help.github.com/articles/repository-permission-levels-for-an-organization/

@blackleg @geertjanw Thanks. Seeing as most contributors won't have write access to this repository, does it make sense that they can't request a review? Will committers know to regularly review new PRs?

Like I said, I’m not sure if this is true. And, yes, committers know to regularly review, that’s what I’ve been asking on the mailing list. And anyone can review, not just committers. Will you review some too, and, no, you don’t need to be an expert, just read the PR and give your opinion.
To me, looks OK, even though I don't know much about the profiler.

I am not sure what is the problem with _filtering_? As far as I can tell `MessageFormat` can ignore some arguments - isn't that the filtering?

The other part of the proposal is trying to dynamically change parameters of the format. That would break [referential transparency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Referential_transparency). Rather than that, just submit a PR and add additional parameters to the `MessageFormat` call, in my opinion.

Should any form of such PR not be enough (and I don't know why), then there is always option to replace whole _About_ action and the dialog you any app based on top of NetBeans Platform.
Well, unless Míla provides some hint here, I go with this change. It is better than current behavior.

Surely `NbBundle.getMessage()` isn't referentially transparent already?  At least with respect to locale and branding token, otherwise there wouldn't be a need for it.  Filter might have been a bad choice of word (think FilterInputStream) - but, yes, really I'm wanting a way to dynamically (well, at run time) transform the input arguments!

Taking a step back, branding cannot achieve what the OP wants to achieve because it's static, and here  there's a need to transform the input arguments into the message via code.  I've come across, and seen other people with, similar problems in various different areas of the platform, and sometimes hacked around them (including exactly what the OP is doing for this).  I was trying to come up with the least intrusive way we could fix it in one place, rather than PR's all over the platform and / or requiring people to rewrite big chunks of it.

They all come down to needing to change the input arguments to (or wrap entirely) `NbBundle.getMessage()`, _from code_.  Am I right in thinking there is no way to do that currently?  Do you have ideas on a better way to achieve this?
@jtulach yes, in any case.
Merged - thank you!
Thanks @matthiasblaesing :)
OK, merging this.

hey  blackleg, 
i checked your fix -it works as designed.

As i unterstood it right, this jar-file is missing when the setup of the test takes place.
Why not add a "createNewFile" in the setup-function - and leave the build untouched ?

by the way: there are 3 other tests, that failed on project "parsing.nb"

could you fix it in the same pull request ?
grretings, Rik

I've also written a test: https://github.com/JaroslavTulach/incubator-netbeans/commit/bca3514fb0342fa971e918caefcdf3dde00636c9, but it needs to wait before support for JavaScript is also donated to Apache.

In a single execution the locale and branding token are assumed to be constant. Thus `NbBundle.getMessage()` runtime results are _effectively_ referentially transparent.

I believe the `java.text` formatting architecture supports pluggable formatters. Javadoc of [MessageFormat](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/text/MessageFormat.html) mentions `choice` & co. Maybe you want to write another format and somehow plug it in?

To use pluggable formatters we'd still have to be able to wrap or override `NbBundle.getMessage()` to use our own `MessageFormat` to achieve this?

It's not a proposal to break the idea of referentially transparent you're talking about then - it's about being able to override / wrap the default behaviour of `NbBundle.getMessage()`.  That _could_ be abused, but the proposal is meant to be that you still get the same output for any distinct set of input arguments.

At the moment there is an assumption that a module is providing all / the right inputs you need to construct the output message you want, but this doesn't always hold in a platform application (it probably does for translations).  The OP's problem is one, but there are lots of times you might want to calculate something differently eg. turning an `X of Y files` message into an `X files remaining` message, etc.

I am going to need some discussion about this. @JaroslavTulach  @mdindoffer. I have discovered that adding arbitrary parents to a dialog could result in the dialog vanishing if the parent dialog gets closed while the given dialog is open (such as when a temparary dialog like the one in `AbstractWindowRunner.createModalprogressDialog` or `o.n.modules.progress.ui.StatusLineComponent.showPopup`). This change wouldn't be needed if Java wasn't being stupid about Application Modal Dialogs not being on top of all other lesser windows in the given application.
My current solution is to create an interface called `Leafable` with a method called `isLeaf` in Dialog API that windows that don't want to be a parent would implement, but that would result in a mess. Any other suggestions?
@JaroslavTulach I created as new pull request with these badges. https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/pull/434
@DhyanRiktam I changed pull request to create the test jar in the setup function instead using the build system.

Re. "there is an assumption that a module is providing ... the right inputs ... to construct ... message ... but this doesn't always hold in a platform application" - yes, that is the assumption. I'd like to cast permanent `-1` to change of this assumption. Please count my `-1` whenever such voting happens. I believe the right approach is to modify the underlaying module to provide more arguments to `NbBundle.getMessage` to make everybody happy. If nothing else, that at least increases the number of contributors to Apache NetBeans.

> that may influence people using the harness to build their own applications

We should just drop support for the Ant-based build harness IMO.

> We should just drop support for the Ant-based build harness IMO.

Surely _that_ would be a rather drastic change that should involve some discussions with RCP devs on the lists! (PR itself sounds a good idea)

Merging this - it improves the situation, even though not completely. The two failing unittests from `parsing.nb` were tracked to commit 775dafe1d2e0f7288d2bfeb116958227f6e4508d:

https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/commit/775dafe1d2e0f7288d2bfeb116958227f6e4508d#comments

Thanks for working on this.
